text: - [Gonzalo Herreros] Hi, this is Gonzalo
from the AWS Glue team.

And today, I wanna show you
a really powerful feature

that has just been added
to the Glue Studio.

Previously, you will
typically develop your job

using the AWS console,
especially for visual jobs.
And then once you're happy and have tested
the changes to your dev account,

you will need some
external process to promote

to other environments or
integrate with a pipeline
that releases even to production.
In the next few minutes,

I will show you how Glue
Studio integrates with Git
in order to enhance development
and to streamline the deployment process.

I will demo both system
supported on release.
First, AWS CodeCommit, and then GitHub.

We are now in Glue
Studio working on a job.

Whether it's a Visual or
we are writing the Script,
that will be saved to S3 as usual.
Now you have this new tab Version Control

where you can link the job
with a code repository.
This in term can be used to initiate

an automatic CI/CD pipeline
that deploys those changes
to other accounts.
In terms of Version Control,

Git is the industry standard
for our source code management.
So by pushing your work there,

we leverage its capabilities
to manage our job history
including the Visual design, the Script,
and any job configuration we have.
At release time, the repository choices
are AWS Code Commit, and Github.

With other popular repositories
to be added later on.

In the case of AWS Code Commit,
it is quite easy to setup.

All we have to do is select
one of the repositories
available in the account.

We need the branch already
created, for instance, main.

And finally, we can enter
a path under the repository

where we store the files
related to this job.
And it can be also a sub-folder.

Now that we have configured
our repository information,
we can use the Action to push the changes

that we have of this
job, up to the repository
so it gets version there.

It asks us to confirm
that we are uploading

to the right repository,
branch and control system.

If we are happy with the
changes, we just confirm.
And the changes will get uploaded.
We are now in Code Commit.

And we can see that for the
repository and branch selected,
we have under the path specified

the files that represent
the job that we have saved.

In this case, there's only a
JSON because it's Visual job.
If it was a Script job,
we'll have the JSON with the configuration

and the separate script
that contains the code.
Now the other action we have available
is Pull from Repository.

What this does is, it
gets the latest version
from the selected branch

and replaces the local job
here with that version.
That's something that we want to do

because we want to
discard the local changes,

or somebody make changes
to the repository directly,

or just because we want
to change the branch.

In the case of GitHub,
the Actions work the same,

but the configuration
is slightly different.

In this case, we have to
enter a personal access token

we generate at GitHub that
will associate the token
with the account and the permissions.
We will see this later.

And you also have to
enter repository owner.

This is the user or their
organization in GitHub
that owns the repositories.
Once we have entered these two things,

we can list the repositories
for that owner and that token.

And from them we will select
the branch in similar way.

Okay, so we are now in
GitHub to generate the token
we need for the integration.
We just have to get from the settings page
to the Developer settings.

Then Personal access
tokens, Generate new token.

Enter a meaningful name
that you can remember later.

Then select how long do you
want this token to be valid for.

Once it's expired, you
will have to set it again
in Glue Studio to be able to integrate.

And finally, you just need
the read and write permission
for the package.

And it will select automatically
the only ones it needs.
Generate the token,
and copy it over.
Back in Glue Studio,

I have entered the token
I generated in GitHub.
Entered the repository owner.

And now I can list
repositories and branches,

and pick the one that I want
to use to save this work.

Once that's ready, I can Push
and save my changes in Github.
Once I have pushed my changes into GitHub,
I can go and check under the repository
that I selected for the path I entered.
My file has been changed
with all the metadata and my visual job.

And now I can use all
the features in GitHub

to check the history,
maybe I want to rollback
and see the times, et cetera.

With this new feature,
we can now streamline

the development and
deployment of your Glue jobs.
Thank you for listening.
